elements.content: In the present study, a hierarchical Co9S8@ZnAgInS heterostructural cage was developed for the first time which can photocatalytically produce hydrogen and degrade organic pollutants with high efficiency. First, the Co9S8 dodecahedron was synthesized using a metal–organic framework (MOFs) material, ZIF-67, as a precursor, then two kinds of metal sulfide semiconductors were elaborately integrated into a hierarchical hollow heterostructural cage with coupled heterogeneous shells and 2D nanosheet subunits. The artfully designed hollow heterostructural composite exhibited remarkable photocatalytic activity without using any cocatalysts, with a 9395.3 μmol g–1 h–1 H2 evolution rate and high degradation efficiency for RhB. The significantly enhanced photocatalytic activity can be attributed to the unique architecture and intimate-contact interface between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS, which promote the transfer and separation of the photogenerated charges, increase light absorption, and offer large surface area and active sites. This work presents a new strategy to design highly active semiconductor photocatalysts by using MOF materials as precursors and coupling of metal sulfide semiconductors to form hollow architecture dodecahedron cages with an intimate interface.

elements.content: To address the current environmental and energy crises, utilization of solar-light driven semiconductor photocatalysis for pollutants degradation and hydrogen generation has shown great potential. Up to now, a lot of semiconductor materials have been developed for photocatalysis. Unfortunately, most of the developed single-component photocatalysts suffer from poor photocatalytic activity. The unsatisfactory photocatalytic efficiency can be mainly ascribed to the narrow light-absorption range, fast charge-recombination, as well as limited redox ability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

To address the current environmental and energy crises, utilization of solar-light driven semiconductor photocatalysis for pollutants degradation and hydrogen generation has shown great potential. Up to now, a lot of semiconductor materials have been developed for photocatalysis. Unfortunately, most of the developed single-component photocatalysts suffer from poor photocatalytic activity. The unsatisfactory photocatalytic efficiency can be mainly ascribed to the narrow light-absorption range, fast charge-recombination, as well as limited redox ability.

elements.content: Metal sulfides (e.g., CdS, Co9S8, ZnAgInS) have attracted wide attention for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution and pollutant degradation owing to their unique electronic, optical, and photocatalytic properties. For example, ZnAgInS quantum dots, ZnAgInS nanosheets, and noble-metal-free cobalt sulfide (Co x S y ) exhibited high photocatalytic efficiencies for hydrogen evolution. In particular, rational coupling of two kinds of metal sulfide semiconductors with suitable band structures to form heterostructure can effectively promote the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges owing to the potential gradient in the heterogeneous interface. Moreover, the hybrid photocatalysts can also gain improved light absorption and photostability. These can render the metal sulfide heterostructures with reinforced photocatalytic performances. Besides the control of chemical composition, in order to realize a highly efficient photocatlytic reaction, rational design of the heterojunction structure is important.

For example, ZnAgInS quantum dots, ZnAgInS nanosheets, and noble-metal-free cobalt sulfide (Co x S y ) exhibited high photocatalytic efficiencies for hydrogen evolution. In particular, rational coupling of two kinds of metal sulfide semiconductors with suitable band structures to form heterostructure can effectively promote the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges owing to the potential gradient in the heterogeneous interface. Moreover, the hybrid photocatalysts can also gain improved light absorption and photostability. These can render the metal sulfide heterostructures with reinforced photocatalytic performances. Besides the control of chemical composition, in order to realize a highly efficient photocatlytic reaction, rational design of the heterojunction structure is important.

elements.content: In recent years, as photocatalysts for solar energy conversion, hollow structual materials have attracted much attention. The hollow structure can not only afford large surface area and abundant active sites for photocatalytic reactions but also shorten the bulk-to-surface distance to accelerate the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges. Moreover, hollow structures, especially polyhedral cages, can significantly strengthen light absorption owing to internal multilight reflection/scattering. In addition, growing two-dimensional (2D) semiconductor nanosheets on the surface of polyhedral cages is highly beneficial to increasing the exposed catalytic active sites and reducing the length for charge diffusion. Therefore, taking the above factors into consideration, it is promising to create a new kind of high-efficiency photocatalyst.

elements.content: In this study, we rationally designed and constructed a hierarchical heterostructural cage Co9S8@ZnAgInS via growing ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surface of Co9S8, which is a hollow structured polyhedral cage. The synthetic route for constructing the hierarchical heterostructural cage is schematically illustrated in . Starting with a metal–organic framework (MOF) material of zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) as a precursor, ZIF-67 is converted to an amorphous cobalt sulfide via a sulfidation reaction. During the sulfidation process, the S ions released from the decomposition of thioacetamide react with the Co ions on the surface of ZIF-67 and generate an outermost layer of cobalt sulfide. Further reactions between the inward diffused S ions and the outward diffused Co ions supply the growth of the cobalt sulfide shell and finally form the cobalt sulfide hollow structure. Afterward, the amorphous cobalt sulfide is transformed to the Co9S8 crystal with a dodecahedral hollow structure through an annealing treatment in a nitrogen atmosphere. Finally, hierarchical heterostructured Co9S8@ZnAgInS is produced after growing a layer of ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surface of the Co9S8 cages by a solvothermal procedure. The growth of ZnAgInS nanosheets on Co9S8 cages is favorable to forming an intimate interfacial contact, which is highly beneficial for efficient charge transfer and separation in the hybrids. In this work, ZIF-67, a kind of Co-containing MOF, is used as a both sacrificial template and a metal precursor to prepare hollow Co9S8 polyhedrons. Compared with solid Co9S8 nanoparticles, the hollow Co9S8 polyhedrons present anisotropic shapes, expose more edges and facets, and endow more surface active sites and better light harvesting. Consequently, the as-prepared Co9S8@ZnAgInS composite presents superior photocatalytic activity and high stability for pollutants degradation and hydrogen evolution.

elements.content: 1,4-Benzoquinone (BQ), triethanolamine (TEOA), isopropanol (IPA), and Rhodamine B (Rh B) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Cobaltous nitrate (Co­(NO3)2·6H2O), 2-methylimidazole, silver nitrate (AgNO3), zinc acetate (Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O), indium acetate (In­(OAc)3), thioacetamide (TAA), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), methanol, ethanol, and glycerol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Milli-Q water was used in the experiments. All other chemical reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

1,4-Benzoquinone (BQ), triethanolamine (TEOA), isopropanol (IPA), and Rhodamine B (Rh B) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Cobaltous nitrate (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O), 2-methylimidazole, silver nitrate (AgNO3), zinc acetate (Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O), indium acetate (In(OAc)3), thioacetamide (TAA), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), methanol, ethanol, and glycerol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Milli-Q water was used in the experiments. All other chemical reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification.

elements.content: The ZIF-67 polyhedrons were synthesized through a modified precipitation method. Typically, 1.28 g of 2-methylimidazole and 0.7 g of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 60 mL of methanol. Afterward, the two solutions were mixed rapidly and aged at room temperature for 6 h. The obtained ZIF-67 precipitates were washed with ethanol two times and then dispersed in ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Preparation of ZIF-67 Polyhedrons

The ZIF-67 polyhedrons were synthesized through a modified precipitation method. Typically, 1.28 g of 2-methylimidazole and 0.7 g of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O were dissolved in 60 mL of methanol. Afterward, the two solutions were mixed rapidly and aged at room temperature for 6 h. The obtained ZIF-67 precipitates were washed with ethanol two times and then dispersed in ethanol.

elements.content: The obtained ZIF-67 polyhedrons were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol by sonication. Then, 0.4 g of TAA was dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol and added to the solution with magnetic stirring for 10 min. The obtained suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained in a preheated oven at 180 °C for 3 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was centrifuged, and the obtained precipitate was collected after washing three times with ethanol. The resultant product was dried overnight at 60 °C in a vacuum. Finally, the Co9S8 dodecahedral cages were obtained by annealing the cobalt sulfide product in nitrogen flow at 550 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min–1 and maintaining at this temperature for 6 h.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Co9S8 Dodecahedral Cages

The obtained ZIF-67 polyhedrons were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol by sonication. Then, 0.4 g of TAA was dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol and added to the solution with magnetic stirring for 10 min. The obtained suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained in a preheated oven at 180 °C for 3 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was centrifuged, and the obtained precipitate was collected after washing three times with ethanol. The resultant product was dried overnight at 60 °C in a vacuum. Finally, the Co9S8 dodecahedral cages were obtained by annealing the cobalt sulfide product in nitrogen flow at 550 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min-1 and maintaining at this temperature for 6 h.

elements.content: Eight milliliters of glycerol, 30 mL of H2O (pH = 2.5), and certain amounts of the Co9S8 (e.g., 4, 10, 16, and 30 mg) were mixed and stirred for 30 min. Then, 0.146 g of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 0.0226 g of AgNO3, 0.389 g of In­(OAc)3, and 0.2 g of TAA were added into the solution. Subsequently, the solution was stirred for 5 min and put into an oil bath at 80 °C under stirring. After reaction for 2 h, the product was obtained by centrifuging and washing three times with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Co9S8@ZnAgInS

Eight milliliters of glycerol, 30 mL of H2O (pH = 2.5), and certain amounts of the Co9S8 (e.g., 4, 10, 16, and 30 mg) were mixed and stirred for 30 min. Then, 0.146 g of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O, 0.0226 g of AgNO3, 0.389 g of In(OAc)3, and 0.2 g of TAA were added into the solution. Subsequently, the solution was stirred for 5 min and put into an oil bath at 80 °C under stirring. After reaction for 2 h, the product was obtained by centrifuging and washing three times with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum overnight.

elements.content: The as-prepared Co9S8@ZnAgInS composites with 2, 5, 8, and 15 wt % Co9S8 are named Co9S8@ZnAgInS-2, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS-15, respectively. For comparison, bare ZnAgInS was synthesized under the same reaction conditions without the addition of Co9S8.
elements.clean_text: The as-prepared Co9S8@ZnAgInS composites with 2, 5, 8, and 15 wt % Co9S8 are named Co9S8@ZnAgInS-2, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS-15, respectively. For comparison, bare ZnAgInS was synthesized under the same reaction conditions without the addition of Co9S8.

elements.content: The morphologies and sizes of the obtained products were measured with a JEOL JEM-2010F transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer operating at 200 kV. The crystal phases of the products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) recording by a Rigaku D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The chemical compositions of the samples were analyzed by the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS, PHI Quantum 2000) with the reference of the C 1s peak (284.6 eV). UV–vis absorption spectra of the samples were measured with a Hitachi 3010 UV–vis spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan). UV–vis–NIR diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrometer using BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the samples were recorded using an F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer with 330 nm of excitation wavelength at room temperature. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface areas of the products were measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The morphologies and sizes of the obtained products were measured with a JEOL JEM-2010F transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer operating at 200 kV. The crystal phases of the products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) recording by a Rigaku D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The chemical compositions of the samples were analyzed by the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS, PHI Quantum 2000) with the reference of the C 1s peak (284.6 eV). UV-vis absorption spectra of the samples were measured with a Hitachi 3010 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan). UV-vis-NIR diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrometer using BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the samples were recorded using an F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer with 330 nm of excitation wavelength at room temperature. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas of the products were measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus.

elements.content: Photocatalytic experiments were performed with an SGY-IB multifunction photochemical reactor (Nanjing Sidongke Electric Co. Ltd.). In a typical experiment, 10 mg of catalyst and 20 mL of RhB aqueous solution (60 mg·L–1) were mixed in a quartz cuvette. The suspension was first stirred in the dark for 30 min to attain an adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the catalyst and dye. Then, the photoreaction vessels were exposed to the irradiation of simulated solar light produced by a 300 W Xe lamp (PL-X500D) whose wavelength distribution is similar to that of solar light. The reaction solutions were analyzed by recording the variation of the maximum absorption band (554 nm) of RhB in UV–vis spectra at given time intervals.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Degradation of RhB

Photocatalytic experiments were performed with an SGY-IB multifunction photochemical reactor (Nanjing Sidongke Electric Co. Ltd.). In a typical experiment, 10 mg of catalyst and 20 mL of RhB aqueous solution (60 mg⋅L-1) were mixed in a quartz cuvette. The suspension was first stirred in the dark for 30 min to attain an adsorption-desorption equilibrium between the catalyst and dye. Then, the photoreaction vessels were exposed to the irradiation of simulated solar light produced by a 300 W Xe lamp (PL-X500D) whose wavelength distribution is similar to that of solar light. The reaction solutions were analyzed by recording the variation of the maximum absorption band (554 nm) of RhB in UV-vis spectra at given time intervals.

elements.content: Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments were operated on an outer Pyrex irradiation cell which was connected to a closed gas circulation system. In a typical experiment, 20 mg of the sample of catalyst was dispersed in 100 mL of aqueous solution containing 10 vol % triethanolamine (TEOA). Before the reaction, the system was vacuumed thoroughly and introduced nitrogen. The photocatalytic reaction was initiated by using a 300 W Xe-lamp (PLS-SXE300). The amount of generated H2 was analyzed with an online GC7900 gas chromatograph.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution

Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments were operated on an outer Pyrex irradiation cell which was connected to a closed gas circulation system. In a typical experiment, 20 mg of the sample of catalyst was dispersed in 100 mL of aqueous solution containing 10 vol % triethanolamine (TEOA). Before the reaction, the system was vacuumed thoroughly and introduced nitrogen. The photocatalytic reaction was initiated by using a 300 W Xe-lamp (PLS-SXE300). The amount of generated H2 was analyzed with an online GC7900 gas chromatograph.

elements.content: The photocurrents were determined using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660A, Chen Hua Instruments, Shanghai, China) with a standard three-electrode system. The system employed Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and the as-prepared photocatalysts as working electrodes. Next, 0.1 mol/L of Na2SO4 solution was used as the supporting electrolyte and a 300 W Xe lamp was utilized as a light source. The photocurrent intensities were measured at 0.0 V with the light on and off. The Nyquist plots were measured over a 100–106 Hz of frequency range at open circuit.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical and Photoelectrochemical Measurements

The photocurrents were determined using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660A, Chen Hua Instruments, Shanghai, China) with a standard three-electrode system. The system employed Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and the as-prepared photocatalysts as working electrodes. Next, 0.1 mol/L of Na2SO4 solution was used as the supporting electrolyte and a 300 W Xe lamp was utilized as a light source. The photocurrent intensities were measured at 0.0 V with the light on and off. The Nyquist plots were measured over a 100-106 Hz of frequency range at open circuit.

elements.content: and Figures S1 and S2 present the TEM and SEM images of pure ZnAgInS, Co9S8, and composite Co9S8@ZnAgInS, respectively. As shown in these figures, pristine ZnAgInS displays a microsphere morphology, which is composed of many cross-linked nanosheets. Co9S8 exhibits polyhedral cage morphology with hollow architecture. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS is a hierarchical heterostructred cage, in which ZnAgInS nanosheets are randomly dispersed on the surface of Co9S8 polyhedrons. The assembled heterostructure with an intimate-contact interface is very favorable for efficient charge transfer between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. HRTEM images of ZnAgInS and Co9S8 reveal the highly crystalline nature of the as-prepared products (d and e). The lattice spacings of 0.33 and 0.28 nm correspond to the (101) planes of ZnAgInS and (222) planes of cubic Co9S8, respectively, which are consistent with a previous report. The HRTEM image of Co9S8@ZnAgInS further confirms the formation of a heterostructure between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS (f).

elements.content: The chemical composition of the product was confrimed by EDX spectroscopy. As shown in g and Figure S3, all of the elements including Zn, Ag, In, Co, and S are detected in Co9S8@ZnAgInS, indicating that the exact ingredients are integrated into the product desirably. The weight percentages of elements in Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 are shown in g. The content of Co9S8 in the optimized Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 heterostructre is about 5% determined by EDX, which is consistent with the theory value. EDX mapping is further employed to identify the composition and internal structure of the composite. As shown in , the element of Co is mainly distributed in the polyhedral cage, while the elements of Zn, Ag, In, and S are homogeneously distributed throughout the whole composite. These results further confirm that the composite possesses a polyhedral cage morphology with hollow architecture in which the ZnAgInS nanosheets are randomly coated on the surface of polyhedral cage Co9S8.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to elucidate the surface composition and chemical states of the Co9S8@ZnAgInS. In a, the XPS survey spectrum of Co9S8@ZnAgInS indicates that the composite is composed of Zn, Ag, In, Co, and S atoms, which is in good agreement with the EDX results. The Zn 2p XPS spectrum (b) shows two peaks centered at 1021.3 and 1044.4 eV, corresponding to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2, respectively. As shown in c, the peaks at 373.8 and 367.8 eV are assigned to Ag 3d3/2 and Ag 3d5/2, respectively. For In 3d XPS spectrum (d), the peaks at 444.4 and 451.2 eV correspond to In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2, respectively. e shows the Co 2p XPS spectrum, which contains two spinorbit doublets, in which the first doublet (with peaks at 778.5 and 793.3 eV) and the second doublet (with peaks at 780.8 and 796.1 eV) are assigned to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, indicating the coexistence of Co3+ and Co2+. The remaining two peaks located at 784.8 and 800.3 eV are satellite peaks. The XPS spectrum of S 2p (f) can be divided into two separate peaks, which are centered at 161.2 and 162.5 eV and are indexed to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively. The high-resolution XPS analysis together with the EDX confirm the succcessful synthesis of the Co9S8@ZnAgInS composite.

elements.content: The crystalline phases of the prepared products were determined by XRD analysis (). The pristine ZnAgInS shows diffraction peaks at 21.6°, 27.7°, 47.2°, 52.4°, and 55.6°, which are indexed to (006), (102), (110), (116), and (202) crystallographic planes of hexagonal ZnIn2S4 (JCPDS No. 65-2023), suggesting that the introduction of trace silver does not change the crystalline phase structure of ZnIn2S4. The bare Co9S8 sample can be assigned to the cubic phase of Co9S8 (JCPDS No. 86–2273). For the Co9S8@ZnAgInS samples, besides the typical diffraction peaks of ZnAgInS, two additional peaks appear at 2θ value of 29.8° and 52.1°, which can be attributed to Co9S8. Furthermore, it is observed that the peak intensities of Co9S8 become stronger with increasing Co9S8 amount in the composites. These results validate that the heterostructured Co9S8@ZnAgInS is successfully prepared.

elements.content: The surface areas and porous structure of the products were measured by an N2 adsorption–desorption experiment. As shown in a, all samples exhibit type IV isotherms, suggesting the mesoporous structure of the materials. The pore-size distributions of the samples are estimated by the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) method. The obtained results are shown in b and . The BET specific surface areas of pristine Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are 34.9 and 86.2 m2g–1, respectively. Compared with Co9S8 and ZnAgInS, Co9S8@ZnAgInS shows an increased specific surface area (132.9 m2g–1). It is well-known that the larger surface area can provide more active sites for photocatalytic reactions, resulting in an enhanced photocatalytic activity.

The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of pristine ZnAgInS, Co9S8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS were measured and are shown in a. Pure Co9S8 exhibits broad absorption from the ultraviolet region to the visible region (300–800 nm), suggesting it owns a strong light harvesting capacity. It is reported that hollow structured polyhedral cage Co9S8 possesses a stronger light absorption in contrast to the solid polyhedral Co9S8, due to multiple reflections inside the cavity of the hollow structure. The absorption edge of pure ZnAgInS located at about 560 nm can be assigned to its intrinsic band gap absorption. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS samples show stronger light absorption and extended visible light response in comparison with those of pure ZnAgInS. The absorption edges of Co9S8@ZnAgInS samples show a systematic red-shift with increasing the Co9S8 content. The red-shift and strong visible light absorption suggest that the composite can absorb more visible light to generate more electron–hole pairs. Digital photographs of the samples (Figure S4) show that the colors of bare ZnAgInS and Co9S8 are brown and black, respectively. When the ZnAgInS is coupled with Co9S8 to form a composite, its color changes from brown to brownish black and black, and the color becomes deep with an increasing of content of Co9S8.

As can be seen from b, the band gap values of Co9S8@ZnAgInS decrease with an increase of Co9S8 content, and the band gap values of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-2, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS-15 are estimated to be 2.45, 2.35, 2.10, and 1.85 eV, respectively.

elements.content: The transfer and separation of the photoinduced charge carriers in the interfaces of the composite have great influence on the photocatalytic reaction. The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum is often employed to investigate the behavior of electron–hole pairs. Usually, a higher PL intensity of the photocatalyst indicates a fast recombination of the charge carriers, resulting in lower photocatalytic activity. As shown in a, the pure ZnAgInS shows a strong emission peak located at about 500 nm with an excitation wavelength of 330 nm. Compared with pure ZnAgInS, the PL intensity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS reduces drastically, indicating that the recombination of the charge carriers is decreased dramatically due to the formation of a heterostructred composite with intimate contact of the interfaces between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. Moreover, time-resolved PL spectroscopy was measured to study the charge carrier dynamics of the materials. As shown in Figure S5 and Table S1, the average lifetime of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 (9.97 ns) is longer than that of ZnAgInS (4.18 ns), which further confirms that the formed heterojunction can effectively promote the separation of photoinduced charge carriers.
elements.clean_text:
Photoelectrochemical Measurements

The transfer and separation of the photoinduced charge carriers in the interfaces of the composite have great influence on the photocatalytic reaction. The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum is often employed to investigate the behavior of electron-hole pairs. Usually, a higher PL intensity of the photocatalyst indicates a fast recombination of the charge carriers, resulting in lower photocatalytic activity. As shown in a, the pure ZnAgInS shows a strong emission peak located at about 500 nm with an excitation wavelength of 330 nm. Compared with pure ZnAgInS, the PL intensity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS reduces drastically, indicating that the recombination of the charge carriers is decreased dramatically due to the formation of a heterostructred composite with intimate contact of the interfaces between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. Moreover, time-resolved PL spectroscopy was measured to study the charge carrier dynamics of the materials. As shown in Figure S5 and Table S1, the average lifetime of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 (9.97 ns) is longer than that of ZnAgInS (4.18 ns), which further confirms that the formed heterojunction can effectively promote the separation of photoinduced charge carriers.

elements.content: The interface charge transfer and separation efficiency can be further investigated by the photoelectrochemical measurements. b shows the transient photocurrent response of pure ZnAgInS, Co9S8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS for several on–off cycles. The pure Co9S8 shows a very low photocurrent density, due to its fast recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes. The unmodified ZnAgInS photoelectrode generates an anodic photocurrent with a value of about 1.5 μA·cm–2, while the Co9S8@ZnAgInS shows a much higher photocurrent intensity compared with Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. These results demonstrate that the prepared composite possesses a stronger ability to generate and transfer the photoinduced charge carriers under light irradiation. c reveals the EIS Nyquist plots of the products, corresponding to their charge transfer resistance. The smaller arc radius of the EIS Nyquist plot implies a lower impedance and faster interface charge transfer. As shown in c, Co9S8@ZnAgInS has the smallest arc radius of the EIS Nyquist plots, indicating that the hybrid composite has the lowest resistance in contrast to its single components Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. These results verify the improved transfer and separation efficiency of photoinduced charges in Co9S8@ZnAgInS.

elements.content: The photocatalytic properties of the as-prepared samples were evaluated first by the degradation of RhB under simulated solar light irradiation. As shown in a, the result of the blank test demonstrates that there is no obvious degradation of RhB after irradiation for 25 min, suggesting that RhB is quite stable under irradiation. Both pure Co9S8 and ZnAgInS samples exhibit low photocatalytic activity for the degradation of RhB under simulated solar light irradiation. However, after assembling the ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surface of the Co9S8 polyhedral cage to form the hollow structured heterojunction, the photocatalytic efficiency is substantially improved. Moreover, the Co9S8 content has a significant influence on the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS. As shown in a, with an increase of Co9S8 content, the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS increases and reaches a maximum value at 5% Co9S8. Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 shows the highest photocatalytic activity with 95% degradation ratio of the RhB after exposure under Xe lamp for 25 min. b shows the absorbance spectra of RhB catalyzed by Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 under simulated solar light irradiation as a function of the irradiation time. The main absorption peak of the RhB molecule located at 554 nm gradually decreases with the increase of irradiation time, demonstrating the degradation of RhB upon simulated solar light irradiation. The kinetic behaviors of as-prepared samples for RhB degradation were further investigated. As illustrated in c, all of them fit well with the pseudo-first-order correlation. On the basis of the plots, the calculated degradation apparent rate constants of the catalysts are 0.122, 0.0426, and 0.0029 min–1 for Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, ZnAgInS, and Co9S8 (d), respectively. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 is 3 and 42 times higher than that of ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Figure S6 shows the results of recycling tests of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 for photocatalytic degradation of RhB. The photocatalytic activity does not show a significant decrease in five successive cycles, indicating the high stability of the as-prepared composite.

Both pure Co9S8 and ZnAgInS samples exhibit low photocatalytic activity for the degradation of RhB under simulated solar light irradiation. However, after assembling the ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surface of the Co9S8 polyhedral cage to form the hollow structured heterojunction, the photocatalytic efficiency is substantially improved. Moreover, the Co9S8 content has a significant influence on the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS. As shown in a, with an increase of Co9S8 content, the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS increases and reaches a maximum value at 5% Co9S8. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 is 3 and 42 times higher than that of ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Figure S6 shows the results of recycling tests of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 for photocatalytic degradation of RhB. elements.content: In order to investigate the photocatalytic degradation mechanism, radical capture experiments were performed. Generally, hydroxyl radicals (•OH), superoxide radicals (•O2 –) and photogenerated holes (h+) are the acknowledged active species in the reaction of photocatalytic degradation of organic molecules. The scavenger experiments using three different types of scavengers, IPA (a quencher of •OH), BQ (a quencher of •O2 –), and TEOA (a quencher of h+) over the Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 sample, were carried out to identify the active species involved in the reaction system. shows the photocatalytic degradation of RhB in the presence of different scavengers under Xe lamp irradiation for 25 min. It is found that 95% RhB is degraded with absent scavengers. However, the degradation ratio significantly decreases to 15% with the presence of TEOA (1 mM), indicating h+ is a major reactive species. Meanwhile, the presence of BQ (1 mM) and IPA (1 mM) are is found to inhibit the degradation ratio to 67.7% and 87.0%, respectively, indicating that •O2 – plays a more important role in contrast to •OH in the reaction. Thus, the influence of the active species in the RhB photodegradation reaction follows the sequence h+ > •O2 – > •OH.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Active Species in the Photocatalysis

In order to investigate the photocatalytic degradation mechanism, radical capture experiments were performed. Generally, hydroxyl radicals (⋅OH), superoxide radicals (⋅O2 -) and photogenerated holes (h+) are the acknowledged active species in the reaction of photocatalytic degradation of organic molecules. The scavenger experiments using three different types of scavengers, IPA (a quencher of ⋅OH), BQ (a quencher of ⋅O2 -), and TEOA (a quencher of h+) over the Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 sample, were carried out to identify the active species involved in the reaction system.  shows the photocatalytic degradation of RhB in the presence of different scavengers under Xe lamp irradiation for 25 min. It is found that 95% RhB is degraded with absent scavengers. However, the degradation ratio significantly decreases to 15% with the presence of TEOA (1 mM), indicating h+ is a major reactive species. Meanwhile, the presence of BQ (1 mM) and IPA (1 mM) are is found to inhibit the degradation ratio to 67.7% and 87.0%, respectively, indicating that ⋅O2 - plays a more important role in contrast to ⋅OH in the reaction. Thus, the influence of the active species in the RhB photodegradation reaction follows the sequence h+ > ⋅O2 - > ⋅OH.

elements.content: The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated under simulated solar light irradiation using ascorbic acid (AA) as a scavenger. As shown in , bare Co9S8 is almost inactive to photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, probably due to its high recombination rate of photoinduced charges. Pristine ZnAgInS exhibits low photocatalytic activity with a H2 evolution rate of 2171.3 μmol g–1 h–1. However, after coupling with Co9S8 to form the composite Co9S8@ZnAgInS, the catalytic activity is substantially promoted, with the highest hydrogen evolution rate being 9395.3 μmol g–1 h–1, which is about 4.3 and many times higher than that of pure ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Interestingly, the obtained result is also higher than for other similar materials reported in the previous literatures (Table S2). As shown in a and b, the H2 evolution rates over the Co9S8@ZnAgInS composite increase with increasing Co9S8 content, achieving a maximum value of 9395.3 μmol g–1 h–1 with a Co9S8 content of 5%. However, further increasing the Co9S8 content leads to a decrease of photocatalytic H2 evolution rates. It is obvious that the Co9S8 content in the composite greatly affects the photocatalytic activity of the composite. When the Co9S8 content is relatively low (<5%), the enhanced photocatalytic activity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS can be ascribed to the formation of a heterojunction, which accelerates the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges, enhances solar light harvesting, and offers large surface area and active sites for photocatalytic reaction. Nevertheless, excessive Co9S8 causes a reduction in the photocatalytic efficiency. The decrease is probably due to the following reasons: (i) Accompanying the increase of Co9S8 content, the content of ZnAgInS, which is the main activity substance, will decrease relatively. (ii) Excessive Co9S8 may turn into a recombination center for photoinduced charges.

Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution

As shown in , bare Co9S8 is almost inactive to photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, probably due to its high recombination rate of photoinduced charges. Pristine ZnAgInS exhibits low photocatalytic activity with a H2 evolution rate of 2171.3 μmol g-1 h-1. However, after coupling with Co9S8 to form the composite Co9S8@ZnAgInS, the catalytic activity is substantially promoted, with the highest hydrogen evolution rate being 9395.3 μmol g-1 h-1, which is about 4.3 and many times higher than that of pure ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Interestingly, the obtained result is also higher than for other similar materials reported in the previous literatures (Table S2). As shown in a and b, the H2 evolution rates over the Co9S8@ZnAgInS composite increase with increasing Co9S8 content, achieving a maximum value of 9395.3 μmol g-1 h-1 with a Co9S8 content of 5%. However, further increasing the Co9S8 content leads to a decrease of photocatalytic H2 evolution rates. It is obvious that the Co9S8 content in the composite greatly affects the photocatalytic activity of the composite. When the Co9S8 content is relatively low (<5%), the enhanced photocatalytic activity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS can be ascribed to the formation of a heterojunction, which accelerates the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges, enhances solar light harvesting, and offers large surface area and active sites for photocatalytic reaction. Nevertheless, excessive Co9S8 causes a reduction in the photocatalytic efficiency. The decrease is probably due to the following reasons: (i) Accompanying the increase of Co9S8 content, the content of ZnAgInS, which is the main activity substance, will decrease relatively. (ii) Excessive Co9S8 may turn into a recombination center for photoinduced charges.

elements.content: Besides high H2 evolution activity, good reusability is another key factor for highly efficient photocatalysts. shows the recycling tests of the Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 composite for H2 evolution in five successive cycling reactions. The duration of light exposure in each cycle was 4 h. No apparent deactivation is observed in the five successive cycles, indicating the high stability of the as-prepared composite. Furthermore, TEM and SEM images and XRD patterns of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 after photocatalytic experiments were measured. As shown in and Figures S2 and S7, the morphologies and XRD patterns of the samples before and after photocatalytic experiments have no obvious difference, further confirming the high stability of the hybrids.

elements.content: In order to explain the mechanism for enhanced photocatalytic activity, the band edge positions of the conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) potentials of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS were confirmed. As for a semiconductor, the CB and VB potentials can be calculated according to the empirical equation: E CB = X − E e − E g / 2 E VB = E CB + E g X is the electronegativity of the semiconductor estimated by the geometric mean of the electronegativity of the constituent atoms. The X values of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are about 4.23 and 4.71 eV, respectively. E e is the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (E e = 4.5 eV), and E g is the band gap energy of the semiconductor (E g’s for Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are 1.01 and 2.52 eV, respectively). From the calculation, the E CB’s of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are about −0.77 and −1.05 eV vs NHE, and the E VB’s of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are estimated to be 0.24 and 1.47 eV vs NHE, respectively. The VB and CB positions of Co9S8 locate in the forbidden band range of ZnAgInS, hence, the type-I heterojunction interfaces are formed in the Co9S8@ZnAgInS nanocomposite. Under the influence of the built-in electric field, the photoinduced charge carriers migrate rapidly, promoting the separation of charge carriers, resulting in a largely enhanced photocatalytic activity.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of the Enhanced Photocatalytic Activity

In order to explain the mechanism for enhanced photocatalytic activity, the band edge positions of the conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) potentials of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS were confirmed. As for a semiconductor, the CB and VB potentials can be calculated according to the empirical equation: 1       E   CB   = X -   E   e   -   E   g   / 2      2       E   VB   =   E   CB   +   E   g       X is the electronegativity of the semiconductor estimated by the geometric mean of the electronegativity of the constituent atoms. The X values of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are about 4.23 and 4.71 eV, respectively. E e is the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (E e = 4.5 eV), and E g is the band gap energy of the semiconductor (E g's for Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are 1.01 and 2.52 eV, respectively). From the calculation, the E CB's of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are about -0.77 and -1.05 eV vs NHE, and the E VB's of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are estimated to be 0.24 and 1.47 eV vs NHE, respectively. The VB and CB positions of Co9S8 locate in the forbidden band range of ZnAgInS, hence, the type-I heterojunction interfaces are formed in the Co9S8@ZnAgInS nanocomposite. Under the influence of the built-in electric field, the photoinduced charge carriers migrate rapidly, promoting the separation of charge carriers, resulting in a largely enhanced photocatalytic activity.

elements.content: On the basis of the above results, the possible mechanism proposed for the superior photocatalytic activity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS is illustrated in . Under simulated solar light irradiation, both Co9S8 and ZnAgInS can be excited and engender photoinduced electron–hole pairs. The CB of ZnAgInS (−1.05 eV) is more negative than that of Co9S8 (−0.77 eV). Considering the inner electric field and energy band structure of the heterojunction, the photoinduced electrons on the CB of ZnAgInS can rapidly transfer to that of Co9S8, thus inhibiting the recombination of photoinduced electron–hole pairs and prolonging their lifetime. As a result, a significantly enhanced photocatalytic activity can be achieved.

elements.content: In the process of photocatalytic H2 evolution, the electrons on the CB of Co9S8 reduce the H+ to produce H2, while the holes on the VB of Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are consumed by the sacrificial agent (AA). In the case of the photocatalytic degradation of RhB, the photogenerated electrons on the CB of Co9S8 can react with electron acceptors, such as O2, to form superoxide radicals (•O2 –) and •OH radicals which are strong oxidative species to directly degrade organic pollutants. The •OH radicals are generated through an indirect reaction between •O2 – and H2O.

In the case of the photocatalytic degradation of RhB, the photogenerated electrons on the CB of Co9S8 can react with electron acceptors, such as O2, to form superoxide radicals (⋅O2 -) and ⋅OH radicals which are strong oxidative species to directly degrade organic pollutants. The ⋅OH radicals are generated through an indirect reaction between ⋅O2 - and H2O.

elements.content: In summary, we fist obtained the Co9S8 dodecahedron, which was derived from metal–organic framework (MOF) ZIF-67, then designed and fabricated the Co9S8@ZnAgInS heterostructured nanocomposite by growing ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surfaces of Co9S8 dodecahedron cages. The complex Co9S8@ZnAgInS possessing hollow architectures and hybrid shells with ZnAgInS nanosheet subunits can promote the transfer and separation of charge carriers, increase light absorption, and offer large surface area and reactive sites, resulting in a largely enhanced photocatalytic activity for pollutant degradation and hydrogen evolution without the aid of any cocatalysts. This work presents new insight into the design of highly active photocatalysts by using MOFs materials as precursors and coupling of metal sulfide semiconductors to form hollow architecture dodecahedron cages with an intimate interface.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we fist obtained the Co9S8 dodecahedron, which was derived from metal-organic framework (MOF) ZIF-67, then designed and fabricated the Co9S8@ZnAgInS heterostructured nanocomposite by growing ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surfaces of Co9S8 dodecahedron cages. The complex Co9S8@ZnAgInS possessing hollow architectures and hybrid shells with ZnAgInS nanosheet subunits can promote the transfer and separation of charge carriers, increase light absorption, and offer large surface area and reactive sites, resulting in a largely enhanced photocatalytic activity for pollutant degradation and hydrogen evolution without the aid of any cocatalysts. This work presents new insight into the design of highly active photocatalysts by using MOFs materials as precursors and coupling of metal sulfide semiconductors to form hollow architecture dodecahedron cages with an intimate interface.

cln_elements.content:
The ZIF-67 polyhedrons were synthesized through a modified precipitation method. Typically, 1.28 g of 2-methylimidazole and 0.7 g of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 60 mL of methanol. Afterward, the two solutions were mixed rapidly and aged at room temperature for 6 h. The obtained ZIF-67 precipitates were washed with ethanol two times and then dispersed in ethanol.

Preparation of Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> Dodecahedral Cages

The obtained ZIF-67 polyhedrons were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol by sonication. Then, 0.4 g of TAA was dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol and added to the solution with magnetic stirring for 10 min. The obtained suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained in a preheated oven at 180 °C for 3 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was centrifuged, and the obtained precipitate was collected after washing three times with ethanol. The resultant product was dried overnight at 60 °C in a vacuum. Finally, the Co9S8 dodecahedral cages were obtained by annealing the cobalt sulfide product in nitrogen flow at 550 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min–1 and maintaining at this temperature for 6 h.

Preparation of Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>@ZnAgInS

Eight milliliters of glycerol, 30 mL of H2O (pH = 2.5), and certain amounts of the Co9S8 (e.g., 4, 10, 16, and 30 mg) were mixed and stirred for 30 min. Then, 0.146 g of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 0.0226 g of AgNO3, 0.389 g of In­(OAc)3, and 0.2 g of TAA were added into the solution. Subsequently, the solution was stirred for 5 min and put into an oil bath at 80 °C under stirring. After reaction for 2 h, the product was obtained by centrifuging and washing three times with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum overnight.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Preparation of ZIF-67 Polyhedrons

The ZIF-67 polyhedrons were synthesized through a modified precipitation method. Typically, 1.28 g of 2-methylimidazole and 0.7 g of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O were dissolved in 60 mL of methanol. Afterward, the two solutions were mixed rapidly and aged at room temperature for 6 h. The obtained ZIF-67 precipitates were washed with ethanol two times and then dispersed in ethanol.

Preparation of Co9S8 Dodecahedral Cages

The obtained ZIF-67 polyhedrons were dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol by sonication. Then, 0.4 g of TAA was dispersed in 20 mL of ethanol and added to the solution with magnetic stirring for 10 min. The obtained suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained in a preheated oven at 180 °C for 3 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was centrifuged, and the obtained precipitate was collected after washing three times with ethanol. The resultant product was dried overnight at 60 °C in a vacuum. Finally, the Co9S8 dodecahedral cages were obtained by annealing the cobalt sulfide product in nitrogen flow at 550 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min-1 and maintaining at this temperature for 6 h.

Preparation of Co9S8@ZnAgInS

Eight milliliters of glycerol, 30 mL of H2O (pH = 2.5), and certain amounts of the Co9S8 (e.g., 4, 10, 16, and 30 mg) were mixed and stirred for 30 min. Then, 0.146 g of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O, 0.0226 g of AgNO3, 0.389 g of In(OAc)3, and 0.2 g of TAA were added into the solution. Subsequently, the solution was stirred for 5 min and put into an oil bath at 80 °C under stirring. After reaction for 2 h, the product was obtained by centrifuging and washing three times with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum overnight.

cln_elements.content:
The surface areas and porous structure of the products were measured by an N2 adsorption–desorption experiment. As shown in a, all samples exhibit type IV isotherms, suggesting the mesoporous structure of the materials. The pore-size distributions of the samples are estimated by the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) method. The obtained results are shown in b and . The BET specific surface areas of pristine Co9S8 and ZnAgInS are 34.9 and 86.2 m2g–1, respectively. Compared with Co9S8 and ZnAgInS, Co9S8@ZnAgInS shows an increased specific surface area (132.9 m2g–1). It is well-known that the larger surface area can provide more active sites for photocatalytic reactions, resulting in an enhanced photocatalytic activity.

Optical Properties

The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of pristine ZnAgInS, Co9S8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS were measured and are shown in a. Pure Co9S8 exhibits broad absorption from the ultraviolet region to the visible region (300–800 nm), suggesting it owns a strong light harvesting capacity. It is reported that hollow structured polyhedral cage Co9S8 possesses a stronger light absorption in contrast to the solid polyhedral Co9S8, due to multiple reflections inside the cavity of the hollow structure. The absorption edge of pure ZnAgInS located at about 560 nm can be assigned to its intrinsic band gap absorption. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS samples show stronger light absorption and extended visible light response in comparison with those of pure ZnAgInS. The absorption edges of Co9S8@ZnAgInS samples show a systematic red-shift with increasing the Co9S8 content. The red-shift and strong visible light absorption suggest that the composite can absorb more visible light to generate more electron–hole pairs. Digital photographs of the samples (Figure S4) show that the colors of bare ZnAgInS and Co9S8 are brown and black, respectively. When the ZnAgInS is coupled with Co9S8 to form a composite, its color changes from brown to brownish black and black, and the color becomes deep with an increasing of content of Co9S8.

The band gaps of the prepared products are obtained from the Kubelka–Munk plots (b). The band gap values of ZnAgInS and Co9S8 are estimated to be about 2.52 and 1.01 eV, respectively. As can be seen from b, the band gap values of Co9S8@ZnAgInS decrease with an increase of Co9S8 content, and the band gap values of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-2, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, Co9S8@ZnAgInS-8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS-15 are estimated to be 2.45, 2.35, 2.10, and 1.85 eV, respectively.

Photoelectrochemical Measurements

The transfer and separation of the photoinduced charge carriers in the interfaces of the composite have great influence on the photocatalytic reaction. The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum is often employed to investigate the behavior of electron–hole pairs. Usually, a higher PL intensity of the photocatalyst indicates a fast recombination of the charge carriers, resulting in lower photocatalytic activity. As shown in a, the pure ZnAgInS shows a strong emission peak located at about 500 nm with an excitation wavelength of 330 nm. Compared with pure ZnAgInS, the PL intensity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS reduces drastically, indicating that the recombination of the charge carriers is decreased dramatically due to the formation of a heterostructred composite with intimate contact of the interfaces between Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. Moreover, time-resolved PL spectroscopy was measured to study the charge carrier dynamics of the materials. As shown in Figure S5 and Table S1, the average lifetime of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 (9.97 ns) is longer than that of ZnAgInS (4.18 ns), which further confirms that the formed heterojunction can effectively promote the separation of photoinduced charge carriers.

The interface charge transfer and separation efficiency can be further investigated by the photoelectrochemical measurements. b shows the transient photocurrent response of pure ZnAgInS, Co9S8, and Co9S8@ZnAgInS for several on–off cycles. The pure Co9S8 shows a very low photocurrent density, due to its fast recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes. The unmodified ZnAgInS photoelectrode generates an anodic photocurrent with a value of about 1.5 μA·cm–2, while the Co9S8@ZnAgInS shows a much higher photocurrent intensity compared with Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. These results demonstrate that the prepared composite possesses a stronger ability to generate and transfer the photoinduced charge carriers under light irradiation. c reveals the EIS Nyquist plots of the products, corresponding to their charge transfer resistance. The smaller arc radius of the EIS Nyquist plot implies a lower impedance and faster interface charge transfer. As shown in c, Co9S8@ZnAgInS has the smallest arc radius of the EIS Nyquist plots, indicating that the hybrid composite has the lowest resistance in contrast to its single components Co9S8 and ZnAgInS. These results verify the improved transfer and separation efficiency of photoinduced charges in Co9S8@ZnAgInS.

Photocatalytic Degradation of RhB

The photocatalytic properties of the as-prepared samples were evaluated first by the degradation of RhB under simulated solar light irradiation. As shown in a, the result of the blank test demonstrates that there is no obvious degradation of RhB after irradiation for 25 min, suggesting that RhB is quite stable under irradiation. Both pure Co9S8 and ZnAgInS samples exhibit low photocatalytic activity for the degradation of RhB under simulated solar light irradiation. However, after assembling the ZnAgInS nanosheets on the surface of the Co9S8 polyhedral cage to form the hollow structured heterojunction, the photocatalytic efficiency is substantially improved. Moreover, the Co9S8 content has a significant influence on the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS. As shown in a, with an increase of Co9S8 content, the photocatalytic efficiency of Co9S8@ZnAgInS increases and reaches a maximum value at 5% Co9S8. Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 shows the highest photocatalytic activity with 95% degradation ratio of the RhB after exposure under Xe lamp for 25 min. b shows the absorbance spectra of RhB catalyzed by Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 under simulated solar light irradiation as a function of the irradiation time. The main absorption peak of the RhB molecule located at 554 nm gradually decreases with the increase of irradiation time, demonstrating the degradation of RhB upon simulated solar light irradiation. The kinetic behaviors of as-prepared samples for RhB degradation were further investigated. As illustrated in c, all of them fit well with the pseudo-first-order correlation. On the basis of the plots, the calculated degradation apparent rate constants of the catalysts are 0.122, 0.0426, and 0.0029 min–1 for Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5, ZnAgInS, and Co9S8 (d), respectively. The Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 is 3 and 42 times higher than that of ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Figure S6 shows the results of recycling tests of Co9S8@ZnAgInS-5 for photocatalytic degradation of RhB. The photocatalytic activity does not show a significant decrease in five successive cycles, indicating the high stability of the as-prepared composite.

Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution

The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated under simulated solar light irradiation using ascorbic acid (AA) as a scavenger. As shown in , bare Co9S8 is almost inactive to photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, probably due to its high recombination rate of photoinduced charges. Pristine ZnAgInS exhibits low photocatalytic activity with a H2 evolution rate of 2171.3 μmol g–1 h–1. However, after coupling with Co9S8 to form the composite Co9S8@ZnAgInS, the catalytic activity is substantially promoted, with the highest hydrogen evolution rate being 9395.3 μmol g–1 h–1, which is about 4.3 and many times higher than that of pure ZnAgInS and Co9S8, respectively. Interestingly, the obtained result is also higher than for other similar materials reported in the previous literatures (Table S2). As shown in a and b, the H2 evolution rates over the Co9S8@ZnAgInS composite increase with increasing Co9S8 content, achieving a maximum value of 9395.3 μmol g–1 h–1 with a Co9S8 content of 5%. However, further increasing the Co9S8 content leads to a decrease of photocatalytic H2 evolution rates. It is obvious that the Co9S8 content in the composite greatly affects the photocatalytic activity of the composite. When the Co9S8 content is relatively low (<5%), the enhanced photocatalytic activity of Co9S8@ZnAgInS can be ascribed to the formation of a heterojunction, which accelerates the transfer and separation of photoinduced charges, enhances solar light harvesting, and offers large surface area and active sites for photocatalytic reaction. Nevertheless, excessive Co9S8 causes a reduction in the photocatalytic efficiency. The decrease is probably due to the following reasons: (i) Accompanying the increase of Co9S8 content, the content of ZnAgInS, which is the main activity substance, will decrease relatively. (ii) Excessive Co9S8 may turn into a recombination center for photoinduced charges.
